awd_titl_txt: Culturally Relevant Messaging and the Political Socialization of HBCU Students
awd_abstract_narration:
This project examines the relationship between how political issues are identified, framed, and disseminated to subsequently influence the political interest and participation of Black students at Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs).  The project develops a profile of political attitudes developed by Black college students, examines indicators of political behavior of young Black students, and assesses the efficacy of a campus social media contest for fostering political engagement of Black college students.  The findings have practical application for the development of culturally relevant civics education curricula, new tactics for engaging Black adolescents in politics, insights about digital citizenship, and the ways in which social media are used to produce and distribute micro-targeted culturally relevant political messages.

This research extends Digital Political Socialization Theory (DPST) to advance understanding of the political socialization of college youth.  Specifically, the project assesses how political issues are identified, framed, and disseminated to subsequently influence the political interest and participation of Black students, The research design compares Black students at two Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs) to Black students at one non-HBCU university in Florida.  The multi-method project relies on focus groups, interviews, and a video contest, with 20 students at each study site participating over a 4-6 week period of time.  The research advances knowledge and understanding of Black college youth’s individual and group attitudes, preference formation and expression and, more broadly, political behavior.

This project is supported by the Accountable Institutions Program and the SBE Science of Broadening Participation Program.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Objectives

Despite the considerable research on issues associated with political socialization, our understanding remains limited when it comes to voters who are not white, and even more so concerning young Black voters. In response to this gap, our mixed-methods, field-based research study set out to engage college students attending a Historically Black College and University (HBCU) within the framework of Digital Political Socialization Theory (DPST). This approach allows us to explore the processes through which political issues are identified, framed, and disseminated, and how these processes subsequently influence the political interest and participation of young Black voters.

Aligned with the National Science Foundation's (NSF) Accountable Institutions and Behavior funding priority, this study emphasized research to advance the understanding of Black Americans' individual and group attitudes, preference formation and expression, and their influence on public policy. This alignment paved the way for a focused inquiry into the factors that shape political socialization and engagement among HBCU students. Our investigation was guided by a couple of primary objectives: first, to develop a comprehensive profile of the political attitudes held by Black college students; secondly, to examine the historical and contemporary indicators of political behavior of young Black voters

Building on this foundation, our study engaged 118 Black respondents, aiming to capture a wide array of perspectives by sampling individuals from HBCUs across Florida, aged 18-29. By employing both quantitative survey data and qualitative insights from focus group discussions, our research design facilitated a thorough exploration of these perspectives. Conducting surveys online in English through a self-administered approach, followed by the immediate segmentation of participants into focus groups, allowed for an enriched understanding of participants' perceptions. This dual-analysis framework significantly enhanced the comprehensiveness and depth of our study, bridging the gap between quantitative breadth and qualitative depth to illuminate the complex dynamics of political socialization among the participants.

Intellectual Merit

The study of political socialization agents—family, peers, school, and media—has been extensive, yet the unique ecology of HBCUs and their collective impact on the political development of college-age Black young adults remains underexplored. This gap highlights the need for a deeper investigation into how these agents converge during the formative years of new voters within the HBCU context. .

To bridge this knowledge gap, we embarked on a collaborative endeavor with faculty from HBCUs across Florida. Leveraging a multidisciplinary research team with expertise spanning education, public affairs, culturally relevant messaging, and the history of HBCUs, we crafted a comprehensive study designed to illuminate the nuances of political socialization within these pivotal institutions. Specifically, our team utilized its collective knowledge to explore the formation of voter beliefs and values at the intersection of messaging strategies and culturally relevant communication. This approach allowed us to examine how political messages are received and internalized by the participants. 

Thus, the primary aim was to dissect the mechanisms through which voter beliefs and values were formed, focusing particularly on the role of culturally relevant messaging. Through this lens, we investigated the dynamic interplay between various socialization agents and their cumulative impact on participants. Our investigation provided empirical insights into political participation, highlighting the significance of familial ties and their psychological role in the political development process. As a result this research endeavor shed light on the intricate processes of political socialization of Black youth voters educated at HBCUs, offering valuable perspectives on engaging college-age Black young adults as informed, active participants in the democratic process. Through this study, we contributed to the broader dialogue on political engagement and socialization, underlining the critical role of communication.

Broader Impact

The project significantly advanced our understanding of how racial minority youth, particularly Black college students in the U.S., are politically socialized and engaged. It offered actionable insights that are pivotal for developing culturally relevant civics education curricula and for crafting innovative political messaging strategies tailored to students. Furthermore, the research explored the realms of digital citizenship and the use of social media for disseminating micro-targeted, culturally relevant political messages.

A key outcome of this research is the illumination of how the political engagement of Black youth voters is evolving, in stark contrast to the previously stagnant messaging tactics. These insights are invaluable not only to scholars and professionals within the social sciences but also to a broader audience interested in understanding and engaging this demographic segment, which has been somewhat overlooked due to a lack of empirical data on their political socialization and engagement.

By shedding light on these areas, the project contributes to a more nuanced understanding of political dynamics, thereby enabling more informed strategies for civic participation, educational engagement, and effective messaging. This work underscores the importance of adapting to the changing landscape of political engagement among Black youth, offering a roadmap for enhancing their involvement in the democratic process.

.
